Situation1: Pre-dawn traffic is sparse and holding patterns are empty.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: An official explains that, because of a registration mismatch, the voter must complete a provisional ballot form before the station closes in ten minutes.
Story:
The radio crackled softly in the pre-dawn hush, but the skies were calm—no holding patterns, no urgent reroutes. I leaned back, savoring the rare quiet, when my phone buzzed. It was a reminder: today was election day. I’d planned to vote before my shift ended, but the hours slipped by. Now, with just minutes left, I rushed to the polling station, my mind still half in the control tower. 

At the door, an official frowned at my ID. “There’s a registration mismatch. You’ll need to fill out a provisional ballot form. We close in ten minutes.” She handed me a stack of paperwork, her tone brisk. 

I glanced at my watch, heart pounding. My supervisor expected me back on time—airspace might be empty now, but that could change in an instant. Yet, as a citizen, I was expected to follow every instruction, to ensure my vote counted. The forms felt endless, my hands trembling as I tried to focus. I could almost hear the distant hum of engines, the weight of two worlds pressing in, each demanding my full attention, each unwilling to wait.
